title: These were tuned by a WIZARD! - Noble Audio FoKus Mystique
description: Thanks again to Noble Audio for sponsoring this video! Unleash the music with the FoKus Mystique at the link below:   We got Adam to sit down and check out Noble Audio's FoKus Mystique headphones. Is the bass on these enough to impress Adam, or are they more dud than bud?  Purchases made through some store links may provide some compensation to Linus Media Group.  Want us to unbox something? Make a suggestion at    GET MERCH:   LTX 2023 TICKETS AVAILABLE NOW:   GET EXCLUSIVE CONTENT ON FLOATPLANE:   SPONSORS, AFFILIATES, AND PARTNERS:   PRODUCTS WE USE ON THE SHORTCIRCUIT SET:   FOLLOW US ELSEWHERE ---------------------------------------------------   Twitter:  Instagram:  TikTok:  Facebook:   CHAPTERS --------------------------------------------------- 0:00 Intro 1:17 Multi Driver Setups 2:52 Meet the FoKus Mystique 3:30 What's in the box? 7:37 First Listen 9:38 Noble App 11:25 Labs Data 12:57 Outro

Balanced armature's kind of like a speaker but it's like a wiggly stick instead of a wiggly cone. That's really in depth. If you want to learn more about balanced armatures, we've done a video on Techquickie about it. Multi-driver wireless headphones are not totally brand new to the space but they do tend to be more complex to manufacture and that can introduce a whole host of difficulties. But why would you want more than one driver in your headphone when there's lots of good headphones out there that just use a single driver? Well, think about it like a speaker. You see a lot of speakers that you buy for your desktop or whatever will have multiple drivers. You'll often have a woofer and then a tweeter. What that does is it allows for better sound reproduction across a wider spectrum. You can apply the same kind of idea to a earphone by using a multiple dynamic drivers, or in this case, balanced armatures. So, you can let that big dynamic driver that's in your headphone push all of those low bass notes with a lot of clarity and then let the balanced armatures handle some of the higher notes. Now, this introduces extra complexity in the form of, instead of tuning one driver, you now have to tune three drivers, you have to make sure that they're in sync, you have to make sure that they're in phase, you have to make sure that they're not overpowering one another, which makes EQ'ing more complex as well as requiring more complex circuitry to balance out all of the signals that are being sent.
